search_result.title: Tokyo Olympics: New Jersey highlights at the 2021 Olympic Games
search_result.text:
Looking to follow all of the athletes from New Jersey at the Olympic Games in Tokyo? Our USA TODAY Network team across the Garden State has you covered.

Check back here throughout the Games for the latest updates, from softball's first pitch on July 20 — three days before the Opening Ceremony — through the Closing Ceremony on Aug. 8.

McLaughlin, Mu propel United States 'super team' to relay gold

Sydney McLaughlin of Dunellen led off and Trenton's Athing Mu anchored Team USA's 4x400 to the gold medal on Saturday morning, New Jersey time. The winning time was 3:16.85, almost four seconds ahead of the field.

McLaughlin handed off to Allyson Felix, who became the most decorated American track and field athlete in history with 11 medals, seven gold.

2024 Olympic medals: Who is leading the medal count? Follow along as we track the medals for every sport.

"It's an amazing group of women right here," McLaughlin told the USA TODAY Network. "Once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. I think we all just knew going in it was going to be fast. All we had to do is do our part and just have fun with it."

It is the seventh straight gold for the American women's 4x400, dating back to 1996 in Atlanta.

Earlier this week, Mu had become the first American woman to win gold in the 800 meters since 1986. McLaughlin and Muhammad went 1-2 in the 400-meter hurdles, as both broke the world record.

USA water polo golden again

Ashleigh Johnson made 11 saves as the United States water polo team topped Spain, 14-5, in the gold-medal match. Seven of those were in the third quarter.

It is the third straight gold medal for Team USA, the second for Johnson, Princeton University's first water polo All-American. The United States is the only nation to win a medal at each Olympics since women’s water polo was added in 2000.

Springsteen, American equestrians settle for silver

After the final round of show jumping, Sweden and the United States finished tied with eight penalties. The gold medal was settled in a jump off on a re-designed layout.

Team USA wound up second to Sweden in a replay of the 2018 World Championships.

Jessica Springsteen was the second American jumper, third overall. She and Don Juan van de Donkhoeve went through the jump-off clear, after knocking down a rail during the main competition.

The American trio — Springsteen bookended by veterans Laura Kraut and McLain Ward — went through clear, but Sweden had a faster total time by 1.3 seconds.

More from Tokyo:Jessica Springsteen wins silver medal with U.S. equestrian jumping team

No Americans had qualified for the individual jumping final.

Springsteen, 25, is the daughter of Bruce Springsteen and Patty Scialfa. She learned to ride on her family's Colts Neck horse farm.

USA Baseball falls to Japan in final

Baseball returned to the Olympics in Tokyo after a two-Games absence, and the host country kept the gold. Japan defeated the United States, 2-0, on Saturday at Yokohama Baseball Stadium to win the country's first Olympic baseball gold.

Frazier, the 35-year-old third baseman from Toms River, went 0-for-4 in the cleanup spot on Saturday. Pat Kivelhan, another Rutgers alumnus, did not play.

Both Team USA's losses in the Olympics came against Japan.

It was these Japan had defeated the Americans, 6-3, to claim gold in 1984, but the U.S. won gold in 1988, 5-3.

Gold medals for Gotham FC

When midfielder Julia Grosso converted a penalty kick for Canada, two Gotham FC players earned gold medals. The Canadians upended Sweden, 3-2, in the shootout to win gold, after a 1-1 draw at the end of regulation and two overtime periods.

Striker Evelyne Viens and goalkeeper Kailen Sheridan are both part of Team Canada. However, neither played in the final.

Gotham striker Carli Lloyd scored twice as the United States earned bronze earlier this week.

Sheridan and Viens made their Olympic debuts as Canada defeated Team USA, 1-0, in a semifinal to advance to the gold-medal match.

Springsteen, show jumpers advance to final

Jessica Springsteen put on a good show as the American jumpers moved on to Saturday morning's final. Springsteen teamed with veterans McLain Ward and Laura Kraut to place fifth of 19 entrants with 13 penalties, in the middle of the 10 qualifiers.

Sweden was clean to earn the top spot.

The United States has medaled in jumping in six of the last nine Olympics.

Springsteen, 25, is the daughter of Bruce Springsteen and Patty Scialfa. She learned to ride on her family's Colts Neck horse farm.

Bruce Springsteen:Fans in Japan supporting daughter Jessica's Olympic equestrian dream

Springsteen was an alternate for the London Games in 2012 but didn't participate.

USA Baseball to play for gold

Todd Frazier has a chance to add something new to his resume: an Olympic gold medal.

Frazier went 1-for-3 with a double, a walk, and a run scored as Team USA defeated South Korea, 7-2, on Thursday. The Americans get a rematch with Japan for gold at 6 a.m. Saturday EST.

Frazier, the 35-year-old third baseman from Toms River, was in the cleanup spot on Thursday.

Frazier has already won the Little League World Series with Toms River East American, back-to-back NJSIAA Group 3 titles at Toms River South, and even Major League Baseball's 2015 Home Run Derby.

“What else could better than that, to be honest with you?’’ Frazier said before the tournament. “You’re playing for your country. Usually, I represent my state (New Jersey). Now, I’m representing the whole country. Honestly, I look back at my career, where I started, where I’m almost done finishing it. It’s a pretty good career I’ve had."

Carli Lloyd propels Team USA to bronze

Carli Lloyd scored twice as the United States women's national soccer team defeated Australia, 4-3, to seize the bronze medal at the Tokyo Olympics early Thursday morning Eastern time.

A 39-year-old Rutgers alumna from Delran, Lloyd scored in first-half stoppage time and again in the 51st minute — the eventual game winner. Megan Rapinoe had scored the Americans' first two goals.

Lloyd became Team USA's all-time leading scorer at the Olympics with 10 goals, passing Abby Wambach. Lloyd is also the first USWNT player to score in four different Olympics. She has scored in every Olympic medal match in which she's played, including for gold in 2008 and 2012.

Jersey girl:What Carli Lloyd says about reconnecting with family, fourth Olympics

Lloyd made history just by taking the field to earn her 312th cap, moving into second place on the all-time appearance list for the USWNT and in international soccer overall, women’s or men’s.

Can Gardner grow gold medal?

English Gardner ran the third leg of Team USA's 4x100 on Wednesday night. The Americans finished second in their heat behind Great Britain, which set a national record of 41.55 seconds, and ahead of Jamaica.

Gardner, a 2010 graduate of Eastern Regional, may not be part of the United States team in Friday morning's final — but would receive whatever medal is earned.

The 2010 Eastern Regional graduate is heading to her second Olympics after being selected to the 4x100 relay pool after placing sixth in the 100-meter dash trials. A two-time NCAA champion in the 100 at Oregon, Gardner was part of the gold-medal 4x100 relay at the 2016 Games.

Tiger triumph for Team GB

♦ Princeton alumna Lizzie Bird broke her own British record while finishing ninth in the 3,000-meter steeplechase on Wednesday morning, Tokyo time. Her time of 9:19.68 surpassed her previous best of 9:22.8 from July 12.

Bird is the first British woman to compete in an Olympic steeplechase final. At Princeton, she had been a four-time NCAA Regional qualifier and two-time Ivy League steeplechase champion.

♦ Rudy Winkler, who competed at Rutgers as a graduate student transfer in 2018, wound up seventh in the hammer at 77.08 meters (252 feet, 10¾ inches).

Poland's Wojciech Nowicki won gold (82.52)

Gold medal, world record for Sydney McLaughlin

Sydney McLaughlin has lived up to the hype.

The 21-year-old from Dunellen won gold in the 400-meter hurdles on Tuesday night (New Jersey time), breaking her own world record in 51.46 seconds. She had been the top qualifier, and is the youngest champion in the history of the event.

American Dalilah Muhammad, the reigning Olympic and world champion, finished second in 51.58 — also breaking the world record.

"It’s not one of the hot events that people usually want to watch a whole lot," McLaughlin told the USA TODAY NETWORK. "But we’ve definitely made it something very interesting."

McLaughlin had broken Muhammad's world record (51.9) at USA Track & Field's Olympic Trials in June. She is the first woman to run the 400 hurdles in less than 52 seconds.

The youngest member of the U.S. track and field team in 2016, McLaughlin finished 17th in the 400 hurdles in Rio as a rising Union Catholic sophomore.

While in high school, McLaughlin had won four straight 400 hurdles at New Balance Outdoor Nationals. She was named the Gatorade Girls National High School Track and Field Athlete of the Year in 2016 and 2017. McLaughlin won three SEC titles (400 meters indoor, 400 hurdles and 4x400 relay) as a Kentucky freshman, and was the 2018 NCAA 400 hurdles champion.

"It's all this season's hard work and dedication," McLaughlin said on the NBC broadcast. "It was great to represent my country and have this opportunity. ... It's an awesome opportunity to represent them all back home."

Athing Mu is New Jersey's golden girl

The teen from Trenton has made history.

Athing Mu, 19, won the gold medal in the 800 meters, leading start to finish. Her time of 1:55.21 broke the American record.

Keely Hodgkinson, another teenager, broke Great Britain's record while taking the silver in 1:55.88. American Raevyn Rogers was third for bronze (1:56.81).

"I came with a medal mentality,” Mu told the USA TODAY NETWORK. “I came here wanting a medal.”

Mu is just the second American woman to win the Olympic 800, joining Madeline Manning-Mims from 1968 in Mexico City. She is also only the second member of Team USA to claim gold in Tokyo, following Valarie Allman in the discus.

Athing Mu:3 things to know about Olympics track star at Tokyo games

Mu's family emigrated from South Sudan more than 20 years ago. She has competed for Trenton Track Club since age 6, but did not run at Trenton Central High School.

She set NCAA records in the indoor 600 (1:25.8) and 800 (1:58.4), and outdoor 400 (49.57) and 800m (1:57.73) as a Texas A&M freshman, and anchored the record-setting 4x400 indoors and outdoors. She is a four-time first-team All-American, and captured the NCAA outdoor 400 meter title, and was part of the Aggies' winning 4x400 indoors and outdoors.

Mu turned pro after her freshman season, signing with Nike.

♦ Julia Ratcliffe, a four-time All-America at Princeton from New Zealand, finished ninth in the hammer throw.

Jessica Springsteen fails to advance

Jessica Springsteen has to wait for another chance to compete. Her horse, Don Juan van de Donkhoeve, knocked off one rail in the show jumping preliminary on Tuesday morning (EST).

Only clear riders moved on to Wednesday's individual final. No Americans advanced.

Bruce Springsteen:Fans in Japan supporting daughter Jessica's Olympic equestrian dream

Jessica is the daughter of Bruce Springsteen and Patti Scialfa. She began riding horses 25 years ago when the family moved to Colts Neck.

The team jumping prelim will be Friday morning, New Jersey time.

McLaughlin set for hurdles final

Sydney McLaughlin of Dunellen and Dalilah Muhammad are the top two qualifiers for the 400-meter hurdles final. Both easily won their heats despite rain Monday night in Tokyo, McLaughlin (53.03) by more than a second.

McLaughlin had broken Muhammad's world record (51.9) at USA Track & Field's Olympic Trials in June.

The youngest member of the U.S. track and field team in 2016, McLaughlin finished 17th in the 400 hurdles in Rio.

The hurdles final is scheduled for 10:30 p.m. ET Tuesday.

♦ Rudy Winkler, who competed at Rutgers as a graduate student transfer in 2018, posted the second-best mark in hammer qualifying. Winkler threw 78.81 meters (258 feet, 6¾ inches) on his second attempt, surpassing the automatic standard to advance to the final on Wednesday morning.

Poland's Wojciech Nowicki is the No. 1 seed at 79.78 meters.

Todd Frazier, Team USA baseball remain in contention for medal

The U.S. (3-1) with Toms River native Todd Frazier (0-for-3) in the lineup at third base won an elimination game over the Dominican Republic and plays next on Thursday night, meeting the loser of Wednesday night’s Japan-South Korea matchup for a berth in this weekend’s gold medal baseball game.

More magic for Mount Olive jumper

Keturah Orji had a couple of goals for her second trip to the Olympics. The 25-year-old from Mount Olive wanted to break 15 meters. She also wanted to become the first female American triple jumper to earn a medal.

She didn't quite succeed. Orji finished seventh in the final (14.59 meters/47 feet, 10½ inches) on Sunday night, Tokyo time. She is the first American woman to qualify for two Olympic triple jump finals.

After fouling her final attempt, Orji raised her hands to the stands and took a bow.

Yulimar Rojas of Venezuela broke the world record at 15.67 meters (51-5) on her final attempt while winning the gold medal, raising a mark set two months before she was born. The reigning world champion and Rio silver medalist had opened competition with an Olympic record of 15.41 (50-6¾)

♦ Princeton alumna Julia Ratcliffe, a New Zealander, threw 73.2 meters to qualify for the hammer final sixth.

♦ Lizzie Bird, a Princeton alumna representing Great Britain, earned the 11th of 12 qualifying spots in the steeplechase.

New Jersey women burning up Tokyo track

Athing Mu, a 19-year-old from Trenton, won her semifinal heat of the 800 meters in 1:58.07, the top time in the field. Ajee Wilson of Neptune, the American record holder, finished fourth in her heat (2:00.79) and did not advance.

"It wasn’t one of those races where you start some way and you get mixed up in the middle," Mu told the USA TODAY NETWORK after the race. "It was pretty smooth leading wire-to-wire. I just wanted to start off strong and finish strong as well."

♦ Dunellen's Sydney McLaughlin easily won the third heat of the Olympic 400-meter hurdles Saturday morning (Friday night in the U.S.) with a time of 54.65.

Dalilah Muhammad — who won gold in the event at the 2016 Rio Games — comfortably won the fifth heat at 53.97. McLaughlin had broken Muhammad's world record (51.9) at USA Track & Field's Olympic Trials in June.

♦ Former East Brunswick High School star and NCAA discus champion Sam Mattis threw a season-best 63.88 meters (209 feet, 7 inches) on his second attempt to finish eighth in the discus on Friday night.

Daniel Stahl of Sweden threw 68.9 meters to add the gold medal to his world title.

Delbarton grad anchors USA triathlon relay

Morgan Pearson's Olympic debut didn't go as planned. After a disappointing finish in the triathlon, Pearson posted on Twitter, "Rough day for me. Was feeling awful the entire race — but that is sport and I refuse to make an excuses. I am very sad right now, and feeling a bit embarrassed."

Pearson rebounded in the debut of the mixed relay on Friday. Effort etched on his face, Pearson anchored Team USA to the silver medal.

In the mixed relay, two men and two women each completed a mini triathlon comprised of a 300-meter swim, 7.4-kilometer bike ride, and two-kilometer run.

A Delbarton graduate from the New Vernon section of Harding, Pearson is the first Jersey-raised athlete to win a medal at the Tokyo Olympics. Former Princeton rower Fred Vystavel and his partner Joachim Sutton earned bronze in the men's pair (6:18.99) for Denmark earlier this week.

Pearson finished his leg in 20 minutes and 21 seconds, seven seconds slower than Kevin McDowell, the other American man on the relay. Bronze medalist Katie Zaferes led off for the United States, followed by McDowell, Taylor Knibb, and Pearson. Starting 21 seconds behind Great Britain, Pearson made up four seconds on the swim, slipped to third behind Team GB and three-time world champion France on the bike, and finished 14 seconds back.

Pearson put his hands on his head as he crossed the finish line, and was embraced by his teammates.

More news from the (fencing) strip

Wayne Valley coach Francesca Russo and Princeton assistant coach Eliza Stone fenced three bouts as the United States fell to host Japan, 45-43, to finish sixth in team sabre. Dagmara Wozniak of Colonia had won one of her three bouts as Team USA lost to France, 45-30, in a quarterfinal.

Montclair fencer controversy: Olympian from NJ confronts teammates wearing pink masks in apparent protest

Jumper's quest for history continues

Keturah Orji has moved on to the Olympic triple jump final again. She is the first American woman to qualify for the final twice, having achieved the feat five years ago in Rio.

A Mount Olive and Georgia alumna, Orji's best mark was 14.26 meters (46-9¼) to rank 11th in the field of 12 women. She did not meet the automatic qualifying standard, nor achieve her goal of 15 meters in the oddly quiet Olympic Stadium.

World champion Yulimar Rojas of Venezuela is the top qualifier for the triple jump final (14.77/48-5½), which is scheduled for 7:15 a.m. Sunday New Jersey time.

Orji came into the event ranked sixth in the world, but fourth this season with the American record of 14.92 meters (48-11¼) she set at an April 25 meet at the Olympic Training Center in Chula Vista, California. Rojas, the silver medalist in Rio, is at No. 1 on both lists, at 15.43.

Keturah Orji:4 things to know about Olympic triple jumper from Mount Olive

Orji is the only American in the final. Tori Franklin, who had broke Orji's American record, was 25th (13.68) of 32 competitors.

"The first time, I felt like I was just happy to make it (to the Olympics)," Orji said before leaving for Tokyo. "I didn't have many expectations for myself. I definitely was just happy to be there. It's a fun experience. I was so young, so I was very nervous. ... This year, I want to win a medal. There's more pressure from myself. It's more like a business trip, where I'm going get something done, as opposed to a dream come true. It's more surreal the first time."

Taking to the track (and field)

♦ Trenton's Athing Mu won her heat of the 800 meters (2:01.01), as track and field competition got underway early Friday morning, Tokyo time. Ajee Wilson of Neptune needed a late kick to move into second in her heat in 2:00.02, the third-fastest time overall.

Jamaica's Natoya Goule (1:59.83) will be the top seed when the semifinals are run Saturday morning.

"We were all pretty bunched up," Wilson said on the NBC broadcast. "Getting and maintaining positioning was hard. I didn't want to put myself into a hole. I found my way in and out throughout the race. I'm glad I was able to finish and get the auto qualifier."

♦ Former East Brunswick High School star Sam Mattis threw a season-best 63.74 meters (209 feet, 1 inch) to qualify for Saturday's men's discus final (7:15 a.m. East Coast time). Mattis, who was an NCAA champion at the University of Pennsylvania and served as a volunteer coach with Rutgers' track program, is seeded eighth in the 12-man final. He's the lone American to advance past the prelim.

"Very stoked for him," Sam's father and former coach, Marlon Mattis, said via text message. "Still not 100 percent healthy, but he dug deep."

American foilists take on teams

Jacqueline Dubrovich of Pompton Lakes, gold-medalist Lee Kiefer and the American foil fencing team competed on July 28 and 29. After defeating host nation Japan in the opening round, due in part to Dubrovich's three individual bout wins, the team lost a semifinal to the top-ranked Russian Olympic Committee, 45-42.

Team USA later lost the bronze-medal match to Italy, 45-23, and finished fourth. Dubrovich did not compete in that match as she was replaced by the team's alternate, Sabrina Massialas, following the semifinal loss.

Medal moments on the water

After two failed attempts to qualify, Nic Fink made the most of his Olympics experience.

Fink, a Pingry alumnus from Morristown, finished fifth in the 200-meter breaststroke on Wednesday night, early Thursday morning in Tokyo. He seemed disappointed with his final time of 2:07.93, the fastest of three Olympic swims.

Australia's Zac Stubblety-Cook (2:06.38) claimed the gold medal.

"He is the feel-good story, and it's not just with us (at Georgia)," Bulldogs and Team USA coach Jack Bauerle said of Fink.

"It's sort of like everybody, every coaching friend of mine wanted him to make the team. He is sort of revered, because of his work ethic and his attitude. He's so highly thought of that everyone was happy when he made it."

♦ Former Princeton rower Fred Vystavel and his partner Joachim Sutton earned bronze in the men's pair (6:18.99) for Denmark. Croatia won the gold (6:15.29).

"Watching Fred on the awards dock receiving his bronze medal brought me to tears," Princeton head coach Greg Hughes said in a press release. "It has been such a long, hard stretch of training over these last four years for him to arrive at this point. Through it all, he stayed true to his goals and never faltered. And, in typical Fred fashion, he's done it with such an incredible attitude and grace. He's been an inspiration to all of us and I am so proud to see him win that medal."

♦ Molly Reckford of Short Hills and Michelle Sechser finished fifth in the women's lightweight double sculls, a second behind the winners from Italy.

Jersey judoka retires after Olympics

Colton Brown of Piscataway opened competition in his second Olympics late Tuesday night.

He dominated his opening match at 90 kilograms, earning an ippon, 11-0, at 2:03 to defeat Raphael Schwendinger of Liechtenstein. Brown lost to Turkey's Mihael Zgank in 4:42 in the round of 16.

Brown announced his retirement from judo immediately after after his loss.

"Yesterday I competed in my second Olympic Games here in Japan. I won my first match against (Raphael Schwendinger of) Liechtenstein and then ended up losing a tight match in golden score in the round of 16," Brown wrote on Instagram.

"Although this isn't what I came for, I left all of myself on that mat yesterday. The amount of support I’ve received from my family and friends has been incredible, and I fought with all of you guys in my heart. ...Dreams really do come true if you’re willing to put the work in and have a solid group of people around you. Thank you guys for making my time on the mat an unforgettable experience."

Pingry grad finally gets to dive in

Nic Fink will get a chance to swim for gold in the 200-meter breaststroke. He finished second by one hundredth of a second (2:08) in his semifinal heat, fourth overall. Australia's Zac Stubblety-Cook is the No. 1 qualifier at 2:07.35.

Fink, a Pingry alumnus from Morristown, had won his preliminary heat in 2:08.48, also the fourth-fastest time. It was a big step forward after failing to qualify for Team USA in 2012 and 2016.

The 200 breaststroke final will be at 9:44 p.m. Wednesday.

Superb moments from scullers

♦ Molly Reckford of Short Hills and Michelle Sechser finished second to Italy by 18 hundredths of a second in their lightweight double sculls semifinal. The duo advanced to the final at 8 p.m. Wednesday.

♦ The American men's eight, including Princeton graduate Nick Mead, was third in the repechage to move on to the final at 9:25 p.m. Thursday.

♦ Princeton alumna Claire Collins was part of the women's four which won the B final (6:33.55).

♦ Princeton alumna Gevvie Stone and Kristina Wagner finished fifth in the double sculls.

Tigers take to the strip

Princeton alumnae Katharine Holmes and Anna Van Brummen helped the U.S. women’s epee team finish fifth. Holmes won all three of her bouts with a combined 15-12 touch advantage as the Americans opened the team tournament with a 38-33 loss to South Korea.

Holmes won twice as the United States beat Hong Kong, 42-31. Van Brummen won three bouts in Team USA's 33-28 defeat of second seed Poland.

♦ Foilist Mohamed Hamza, a rising junior at Princeton, advanced to a quarterfinal, losing 15-9 to Alexander Choupenich of the Czech Republic. Hamza had defeated Italy's Andrea Cassara, 15-13, in his first match.

Wozniak comes up short in sabre

Colonia's Dagmara Wozniak advanced to the sabre fencing round of 32, where she fell to Russia's Olga Nikitina, 5-14. Wozniak compete with Team USA in a quarterfinal against France Friday night ET.

American rowers advance

Gevvie Stone and Kristi Wagner earned a berth in the double sculls A final. They finished third in the semifinal in 7:11.14, behind the Netherlands and Canada.

Stone, a Princeton alumna, won silver in single sculls in 2016.

“One of the guys I row with wrote us an email and said the semifinal is like the Wednesday of the work week,” Stone told the USA TODAY NETWORK. “It's kind of true. It's really hard, and it's not the most fun race. But we have to get through it to get to the fun part.”

♦ Tracy Eisser of Fair Lawn and Megan Kalmoe finished second in the women's pair repechage to advance to Tuesday's semifinal. Molly Reckford of Short Hills helped the lightweight double sculls win by nearly six seconds to advance to Tuesday's semifinal.

NJ fencer ousted in close opening bout

Despite a late comeback, Jacqueline Dubrovich lost her opening bout in the individual foil fencing competition in Tokyo.

The 27-year-old Riverdale native and Pompton Lakes High School graduate was eliminated by Germany's Leonie Ebert in the round of 32. Dubrovich gained an early 2-0 advantage, but had to stage a late comeback after going down, 11-14. She tied the match at 14-14 before losing, 15-14.

American Lee Kiefer, a three-time Olympian, won the gold medal.

♦ Princeton alumna Katharine Holmes lost her opening epee bout, 15-12, to Song Sera of South Korea.

Hall hoop alums meet up

Former Seton Hall University basketball big men Patrik Auda and Aaron Geramimpoor, both of whom graduated in 2014, faced off in the opening round of men's basktball's group stages in Tokyo.

Auda, a standout forward for the Czech Republic, tallied 16 points and six boards to lead hi steam to a six-point victory over Iran — for which Geramipoor logged two points and three rebounds.

In the second round of group play, Auda scored 14 on 5-of-10 shooting in a 20-point loss to France.

Rutgers shoutout at Opening Ceremony

Elinah Phillip doesn't swim at Rutgers anymore, but the NBC commentators still noted her New Jersey affiliation as she carried the flag of the British Virgin Islands in the Opening Ceremony on July 23.

Phillip set the Scarlet Knights' record in the 50 freestyle (22.41 seconds) while finishing sixth at the 2020 Big Ten Championships as a freshman. She transferred to Florida International for her sophomore season, and is now a rising junior there.

Phillip became BVI's youngest athlete and the first to represent the territory in Olympic aquatics at the 2016 Olympics.

Alexia Lacatena makes Sussex County history

It's a moment that will forever go down in Sussex County history.

Stanhope native Alexia Lacatena became the county's first athlete to compete in the Summer Olympics when she came on to pitch in relief for the Italian national team against the United States on the opening day of competition on Thursday at Fukushima Azuma Baseball Stadium in Fukushima, Japan.

The 18-year-old Lenape Valley High School graduate took the ball from starter Greta Cecchetti with runners on the corners and no outs in the top of the fifth inning with the Italian national team trailing the U.S. 1-0.

"Right now, the pride of Lenape Valley and the Patriots, having an Olympic moment as a teenager," Beth Mowins said on the broadcast.

"Pretty special moment for the youngster," Michele Smith added.

Lacatena gave up a sacrifice fly, infield single and a walk in the fifth but got out of the jam and tossed a perfect sixth inning. The United States won the game, 2-0.

Lacatena, whose mother was born in Italy and whose father was born in New Jersey but grew up there, has been competing for the European side since she was 15. She was called up to the senior national team at 17, helping them win the European Championship earlier this month.

The Kentucky commit did not compete in her senior season for the Patriots this spring as she prepared to achieve her dream of competing in the Olympics.

"Growing up, it’s always been that I’m going to play in the SEC and next step I’m going to go to the Olympics or play for a pro team," Lacatena said last fall. "It’s always been a goal of mine and it’s just insane to think that it’s happening."

It is the first year softball is back in the Olympics since it was dropped following the 2008 Games.

Lacatena joined snowboarder Danny Kass, formerly a Vernon resident, as the only other Sussex County athlete to compete in the Olympics. Javelin thrower Mike Juskus of Hopatcong qualified for the 1980 Olympics in Moscow but the U.S. team boycotted those games.

Jane Havsy is a sports reporter for DailyRecord.com. For full access to live scores, breaking news and analysis, subscribe today.

Email: JHavsy@gannettnj.com Twitter: @dailyrecordspts

search_result.title: Olympics opening ceremony live updates: Latest highlights from Paris
search_result.text:
USA TODAY

With an ambitious and unique opening ceremony, the 2024 Paris Olympics got under way when thousands of Olympians, including Team USA athletes, cruised along the Seine River on Friday night.

The city’s iconic landmarks provided a stunning backdrop for the parade of nations. Athletes from around the world, including Team USA flag bearers LeBron James and Coco Gauff, floated on boats for the six-kilometer route that traveled east to west across Paris from the Pont d’Austerlitz to the Trocadero.

USA TODAY Sports brought you live updates from Paris, highlights and more throughout the opening ceremony. (Follow NBC's replay of the opening ceremony in prime time.)

Who lit the Olympic Cauldron?

The Olympic Cauldron was lit by Teddy Riner, a three-time Olympic champion in judo, and Marie-Jose Perec, a three-time Olympic champion in track and field.

2024 Olympic medals: Who is leading the medal count? Follow along as we track the medals for every sport.

Rafael Nadal, Serena Williams carried Olympic torch

In an Olympics opening ceremony surprise, Rafael Nadal carried the Olympic torch once it reached the Eiffel Tower. Nadal might as well have honorary French residency after winning a record 14 French Opens. He won four in a row from 2005-2008, five in a row from 2010-2014, another four in a row from 2017-2020 and his final one in 2022. He is 112-4 all-time at Roland Garros. A statue of him was erected outside the stadium in 2021. Nadal has 22 Grand Slams total.

Nadal then passed the torch to fellow tennis legend Serena Williams. Three of her 23 Grand Slam titles came at the French Open. Carl Lewis, a four-time Olympic champion at the 1984 Games, and Romanian gymnast Nadia Comaneci, who scored the first perfect 10 in Olympic history at the 1976 Games, also were part of the torch’s final journey. — Nancy Armour

Amelie Mauresmo passed Olympic torch to Tony Parker

The tennis theme in the Olympic torch relay continued when Amelie Mauresmo, the only French player to be No. 1 in the Open era, took the torch after it arrived off the boat. Tony Parker, who paved the way for French players in the NBA and won four titles with the San Antonio Spurs, took the handoff from Mauresmo. Parker and Carter continued running with the torch after they passed it over to a trio of French athletes. — Nancy Armour

Celine Dion at opening ceremony dazzled

The legendary singer Celine Dion performed at the opening ceremony after the Olympic Cauldron was lit. She also sang at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics opening ceremony.

Eiffel Tower puts on light show at opening ceremony

Watch the iconic Paris landmark sparkle.

Who sang 'Imagine' at the Olympics?

Pianist Sofianne Pamart and singer Juliette Armanet performed “Imagine,” the John Lennon and Yoko Ono song.

Team USA's LeBron James, Coco Gauff not slowed by rain

The rain wasn’t spoiling the party for LeBron James, Coco Gauff and the rest of the U.S. Olympic team.

“Representing the red, white and blue, there’s no better time,” James said during an interview with NBC’s Maria Taylor during the parade of nations. “We’re here for the USA and ready to go out and compete at a high level.”

The NBA superstar and the Grand Slam champion were selected as flagbearers by the rest of the U.S. team. Flagbearers held their country’s flags aloft as the team boats floated down the Seine while other athletes waved smaller flags. But Gauff and James also took time to pose for photos with others on the boat – including the captain – and take in the sights of Paris.

“Seeing a lot of water, first off,” Gauff said. “But also some amazing people, a lot of amazing athletes and we’re all excited to represent Team USA.”

Asked if the steady rain put a damper on their special moment, James said no.

“The rain can’t stop us,” he said. — Nancy Armour

Axelle Saint-Cirel performs French national anthem on Grand Palais roof

On the roof of the Grand-Palais and wearing colors of the French flag, Axelle Saint-Cirel, the Choeur and the Maîtrise de Radio France performed the French national anthem, called The Marseillaise. It was composed in 1792 by Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle, who was an officer for the French Engineers. It was declared the national anthem in 1795. As the national anthem was performed, the Republic Guard raised the flag at the Trocadéro. Composer Victor le Masne musically rearranged the national anthem for the opening ceremony.

Steph Curry, A'ja Wilson at Olympics opening ceremony

Women's basketball forward A'Ja Wilson looks to have added an extra piece of fashion to her Team USA Ralph Lauren outfit — thanks to the help of Steph Curry. The Golden State Warriors guard — who is making his Olympic debut with USA Basketball in Paris — gifted Wilson Olympics-themed sunglasses for Friday's opening ceremony.

Which country will host the 2028 Olympics?

The 2028 Summer Olympics will be in Los Angeles. The city has hosted twice before: 1932 and 1984.

Noah Lyles, Sha'Carri Richardson show off nails at opening ceremony

Here's a look the nails of Noah Lyles, who is the fastest man in the world so far this year.

And here are Sha'Carri Richardson's nails from the opening ceremony.

What country has the most athletes in the Olympics?

There are 10,714 athletes from 206 different countries scheduled to take part in this year's Olympic Games. The United States will have the largest national delegation at the Summer Games in Paris with 593 athletes. Host nation France is second with 573, followed by Australia (460), Germany (427), Japan (404), Italy (403), China (388), Spain (382), Great Britain (327) and Canada (318) rounding out the top 10.

Why was Australia after Zambia and Zimbabwe at opening ceremony?

The sight of the Australian team coming after Zambia and Zimbabwe might have taken those who know their alphabet by surprise. But there was a reason for the Aussies being so far out of alphabetical order. Countries that are hosting upcoming Olympics come at the end of the Parade of Nations. Brisbane is hosting the 2032 Summer Games, so Australia was the third-to-last team. The United States was second-to-last, with the Olympics returning to Los Angeles in four years. And France, the host of these Paris Olympics, was the last country in the 85-boat flotilla. — Nancy Armour

Olympics opening ceremony order of countries

The order of the parade of nations is determined by the French spelling of their country names. Germany is Allemagne in French, for example, so it goes with the As, not the Gs. The only exceptions are the United States, which is Etats-Unis in French but goes second-to-last because it is hosting the next Summer Games, and France, because it’s the host country.

Metal band at Paris Olympics: Who is Gojira?

The metal band Gojira, who performed at the Olympics opening ceremony, is made up of Joe Duplantier, Mario Duplantier, Christian Andreu and Jean-Michel La- badie. They performed at the Conciergerie, which was the residence of French kings in medieval times. It became a prison during the French revolution and Marie-Antoinette was one of its most famous prisoners. Gojira performed alongside singer Marina Viotti.

Aya Nakamura Olympics opening ceremony performance

Aya Nakamura is one of France’s most famous pop stars, performing performed "Pookie, Djadja" and "For me formidable, La Bohéme" at the opening ceremony alongside 60 musicians from the Republican Guard and 36 choristers of the French Army. Nakamura mixes elements of R&B, Afropop and Parisian street slang, and her most famous song is “Djadja.” She’s been compared to Rihanna and Cardi B.

Why Russia, Belarus are banned from 2024 Olympics

Once again, Russia is technically banned from appearing at the Olympic Games. Yet once again, Russian athletes will compete under a different name − a handful of them, at least.

At the 2024 Paris Olympics, which begin this week, 15 athletes from Russia − and 18 from neighboring Belarus − are slated to compete as "Individual Neutral Athletes," or AINs for short, according to the most recent statistics released by the International Olympic Committee on Saturday. The AIN classification means that Russian and Belarusian flags, national anthems and uniforms will be absent from the Paris Games. This punishment was levied by the International Olympic Committee following its invasion of Ukraine. — Tom Schad

How many athletes are on Team USA?

There are 593 American Olympians at the Paris Games. Meet Team USA.

How many countries participate in the 2024 Olympics?

More than 200 countries are competing in the 2024 Olympics, from Afghanistan to Zimbabwe.

Minions at Olympics opening ceremony

Minions — of the "Despicable Me" franchise and its spinoff movie, "Minions" — made a digital appearance at the opening ceremony. In a video with the "unknown" athlete running with the Olympic torch, the Minions are seen acting out a scene in a submarine submerged in the Seine.

Lady Gaga at Olympics opening ceremony gave stunning performance

Lady Gaga returned to music at the 2024 Paris Olympics during a performance at the opening ceremony and lit up the City of Lights. Alongside a fleet of dancers, the Grammy favorite performed a French-inspired set alongside the Seine river with a tribute to Zizi Jeanmaire's presentation of "Mon Truc En Plumes," translated to “My Thing with Feathers.” — Jay Stahl

Olympic opening ceremony performers

Lady Gaga, metal band Gojira and French pop star Aya Nakamura were among those who have performed at the opening ceremony.

Who made medals for the Paris Olympics?

The Monnaie de Paris, which has been minting France’s coins since 864. The company also made the medals for the Athens Olympics in 1896, the first modern Olympic Games, and the two previous Summer Games in Paris, in 1900 and 1924.

How many medals were made for the Paris Olympics?

5,084.

Why does Greece go first in the Olympics?

Greece goes first at the opening ceremony every Olympics because it is the birthplace of the Olympic Games.

Why is Peyton Manning wearing an arm band?

NBC opening ceremony co-host Peyton Manning sported an arm band on his right forearm during the opening ceremony broadcast, much like he did during his playing days as an NFL quarterback. He joked he was wearing it because he had notes on all 200-plus countries in the opening ceremomny.

Giannis Antetokounmpo on being Greece's flag bearer

“That is an honor,” he said. “If I am the flag bearer, great. If I am not, OK. I am just happy that I have a good coaching staff and a good team, I am in the Olympics."

Who designed the Olympics flag?

Pierre de Coubertin, who is considered the founder of the modern Olympics, designed the rings in July 1913. The Olympics logo was first used on a flag in 1914. That original flag is now at the Olympic Museum in Lausanne. The IOC officially adopted the rings logo and flag in 1914.

Americans in Paris

Rachael Raskovich, Amanda Mason-Sekula and Kelly Holmes arrived at the opening ceremony wearing American flag themed hats, red white and blue glasses and sequin USA jackets with "Proud American" stitched on the back.

"Amazon," Raskovich said with a smile when asked about the gear.

The trio of friends met in law school and said they will spend the next week or so hopping around to events around the city. They have tickets to beach volleyball and equestrian, Raskovich said, among other sports. Their group was just one of the many clad in red, white and blue that lined the southern banks of the Seine River on Friday night. Doris Ng of Chicago was among the U.S. spectators who were still searching for a good spot from which to view the ceremony in the hour before it began.

"We thought we were going to be on time," she said. "I think everybody else beat us to the punch already."

Fortunately, she also has tickets to the closing ceremony, she said. — Tom Schad

Not every local was in a festive mood

One man saw my media credential and wanted to make sure — despite barely speaking English — that he was upset over a rumor Celine Dion had been paid 2 million Euros to perform one song at the opening ceremony. Another woman, an American who has lived in Paris for 15 years, said property taxes went up and yet Parisians were not given much access to events or even public spaces to watch the festivities despite the financial and social burden being put on them.

But even when the rain began falling, people did not scatter to look for shelter. Instead they powered through, trying to get a better look at the bleu, blanc and rouge streaks being left in the sky by an airplane flyover.

Restaurants, which don’t have televisions here, were generally not busy. If you were going out to eat Friday night, it’s because you didn’t care to watch the show live. But inside one of them in a residential area near the Eiffel Tower, you could hear the singing of La Marseillaise, the French National Anthem. For a few minutes, the din of conversation went completely silent. — Dan Wolken

Team USA opening ceremony outfit

Team USA’s opening ceremony outfit is a modern take on a tailored look. On top, a tailored single-breasted wool blazer with red and white tipping is worn over a striped oxford shirt. The bottom is a more casual tapered jean and classic suede buck shoe fit.

Ralph Lauren works closely with Team USA and the goal, as always, is to “do something graphic and uniquely American,” chief brand and innovation officer David Lauren said.

To account for the heat, the company constantly looks at different fabrics and layering systems to keep the athlete’s body temperature in check, Lauren said. All items in both the opening and closing ceremony outfits are manufactured in the United States.

Coco Gauff opens up on being U.S. flag bearer, making Olympic debut

Coco Gauff is making her Olympic debut in Paris and she is one of two U.S. flag bearers. “(Competing) in the Olympics has always been up there with winning a Grand Slam, like top goals,” Gauff told USA TODAY Sports this summer. Read our full feature on Gauff.

On the opening ceremony red carpet, Serena Williams was asked about Gauff being the flag bearer. "Isn't that great. I'm so excited to see her tonight. I'm just so happy for her," the tennis legend said.

USA flag bearers 2024

Basketball superstar LeBron James and tennis star Coco Gauff are the flag bearers for the Americans. Gauff is the first tennis player to serve in the role.

Why is Snoop Dogg at Olympics?

With his mind on the Olympics and the Olympics on his mind, Snoop Dogg is, indeed, back for the 2024 Paris Olympics. The rapper, who will carry the torch ahead of the opening ceremony, is primed for a bigger role three years after his reactions to the dressage competition with Kevin Hart went viral at the Tokyo Games.

Snoop will appear regularly on “Primetime in Paris,” serving as a “special correspondent” for NBC. During parts of the primetime show, Snoop Dogg will interact with Team USA athletes, their families, or explore Paris and share his experiences and insights with the night's audience. He's also carrying the Olympic torch.

Paris Olympics closing ceremony date

The 2024 Summer Games will hold the closing ceremony on Aug. 11

How many times has Paris hosted the Olympics?

Paris has hosted the Summer Olympics three times: 1900, 1924 and 2024.

Are any U.S. athletes skipping the opening ceremony?

About 350 of Team USA’s 592 athletes will march – or rather, float – in today's opening ceremony, according to Nicole Deal, who oversees the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee’s security operations.

That means about 40% of the U.S. delegation will be absent, though that is not exactly unusual.

Many athletes and teams – especially those competing early in the Games – choose to pass on the opening ceremony because it often runs late into the night and requires them to spend several hours on their feet. U.S. gymnasts and swimmers, for example, regularly skip the ceremony to rest up for their competitions – which, in some cases, begin the next morning.

U.S. swimming star Katie Ledecky said earlier this week that she never planned on going to the Paris opening ceremony for this very reason. She swims the 400-meter freestyle Saturday morning. — Tom Schad
